text:
I have virtually no knowledge about this stuff, but I would start with two
things:

1. First work on the DocumentRoot, and don't try VirtualDocumentRoot until
you can get that working.

2. Use forward slashes instead of back-slashes.

creator: mbond@mbond.de
text:
If you map a share to a drive letter so that it looks like a normal windows 
drive ( eg k:\webroot\) and use this as the DocumentRoot then you get the same 
error message that the DocumentRoot is not a directory. It doesn't matter if 
you are pointing the DocumentRoot at the root of this drive or a subdirectory; 
Apache does not recognise the directories on a mapped drive as being 
directories.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
Folks. Yes if the server cannot determine the directory it will throw this
message (Joshua, what do you think, is it a FAQ?).

However, how do you start apache as console application? I believe, you actually
don't do and simply start the service instead.

Note if the share is on another network or in another domain - trusted or not - 
and if your local/intranet DNS is broken, it'll resolve intermittently or not 
at all. The server has to see the share when it boots and anytime the Apache 
service is running. DNS is one of those necessary evils that unfortunately can 
work sometimes and sometimes not; there are often many grey areas.

In my case, when I set all my docs up on a RAID - instead of on separate 
servers - for redundancy and some piece of mind, it worked right out of the 
box. I got it to see the DocumentRoot from different servers (after some conf 
tweaks), even the php, databases, the whole lot. When my DNS went twiddly about 
three days later, I started receiving the above message and had a helluva time 
straightening it out.
creator: bugzilla@evilprince.com
wrowe@apache.org
text:
The syntax is

DocumentRoot //machine/share/path

and requires that you set apache 2 to "Run As" a user with permissions
to that share.

bugzilla's not a troubleshooting forum, fwiw.  The user list is for that.
